FAQs.question: What is Gonorrhea?
FAQs.answer: Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

FAQs.question: How is Gonorrhea transmitted?
FAQs.answer: Gonorrhea is spread through vaginal, anal, or oral sex with an infected person.

FAQs.question: What are the symptoms of Gonorrhea?
FAQs.answer: Symptoms may include painful urination, abnormal discharge, or no symptoms at all.

FAQs.question: Can Gonorrhea be cured?
FAQs.answer: Yes, Gonorrhea can be treated and cured with antibiotics.

FAQs.question: What happens if Gonorrhea is left untreated?
FAQs.answer: Untreated Gonorrhea can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), infertility, and other serious health issues.

FAQs.question: Can Gonorrhea be asymptomatic?
FAQs.answer: Yes, many people, especially women, may not show symptoms.

FAQs.question: How can I prevent Gonorrhea?
FAQs.answer: Using condoms and getting regular STI screenings can help prevent Gonorrhea.

FAQs.question: Can Gonorrhea affect pregnancy?
FAQs.answer: Yes, Gonorrhea can cause complications during pregnancy and can be passed to the baby during childbirth.

FAQs.question: Can I get Gonorrhea more than once?
FAQs.answer: Yes, reinfection is possible even after treatment if exposed again.

FAQs.question: How is Gonorrhea diagnosed?
FAQs.answer: Gonorrhea is diagnosed through urine tests or swabs of the affected area.
